Military shipyards are usually top-secret affairs, with even the lowest-level workers thoroughly vetted and cleared. The Mavros eschew this approach, preferring to throw open the gates of design and construction to anyone who has bright ideas or a helping hand to make the fleet bigger, faster, and deadlier.

One of many tweaks the Endless made to Mavros physiology was adapting them to the hottest planets in the galaxy, and the Mavros in turn have adapted their industry to best suit these scorching worlds. Hadeo-Industrial plants burrow deep into the planetary crust, drawing on geothermal energy, and freeing up the surface for miles upon miles of solar panels.

Stuck on poor-quality planets by their Endless masters, the Mavros are no strangers to hardship and shortages. It may seem grim to others, but to them, rationing has gone beyond a necessity and become an inextricable part of their cultural heritage, such that even wealthy Mavros families on plentiful worlds will 'ration' their resources out of a sort of ritual.

With massive forcefields and layer upon layer of multi-composite armour, these structures are well-protected from orbital assault, and with miles of transit tunnels linking gigantic underground modular warehouses, they offer vital military logistics and infantry bases. However, its true purpose is surveillance - via ground telescope arrays and satellite links - of the surrounding space. The Mavros are determined never to be caught unawares.

Once upon a time, Mavros engineers designed a system of impervious subterranean bunkers, city-wide energy shields, resource caches, concealed supply lines, multiply-redundant infrastructure, and AI-controlled satellite networks to make their planets impervious to attack. Then someone said "why don't we just build some really big guns and aim them upwards?", and the rest is history.

If a Mavros ever says they're not currently working on some pet project, their friends will immediately inquire what's wrong. It stands to reason that for such a naturally industrious people, one of the best ways to increase industrial production is simply to make it easier for every citizen to 3d-print whatever they like. Even if only one in ten find commercial success, the public printing stations are still paying for themselves.
The garrison of this system gains a high degree of autonomy thanks to the ability of newly installed cyborg tacticians. The empire can create larger fleets without fear of disorder.

The luxuries lottery employed by many of the galaxy's factions is of little interest to the Mavros. They much prefer to receive a windfall of strategic resources, which can then be used kitting out their personal power armour, combat vehicle, or spaceship.

Drudges are sentient but unfeeling robots that do all the things the Mavros find "boring". They are in charge of all agricultural operations, and act as political organizers, trade company managers, and fulfil most roles that don't directly relate to tinkering, building, or fighting. They may be upgraded in the future.

Drudge Titans are sky-scraper tall sentient robots that, when idle, are utilized as commerce and research processing centers. However, when a solar system is being invaded they awaken and deal devastating damage.

Though some view the Savrons as mere Sophon renegades, they are a different society with a different mentality, even if they share much of their genetic code. While both enjoy tinkering, technology, and discovery, the Savrons have a tendency to use these things to plunder, pirate, and conquer. They are adventurers and scavengers who, while not being as smart, have double the attitude. A common epithet of their bounty-hunting society is, "Unbreakable toys can be used to break other toys."
Often found as mercenaries and enforcers; the Savron's small size is compensated with technology and belligerence.
